abstract.p: Dr Harold S Koplewicz letter says Jon Corzine made substantial philanthropic contributions long before his New Jersey Senate bid, including gifts to New York University Child Study Center where Koplewicz is director; says Corzine is one of those rare people who give anonymously (S)

block.p: Critics have said that philanthropic contributions from Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic candidate for Senate in New Jersey, were linked to political favors (news article, Oct. 9). But long before he decided to run for office, Mr. Corzine made substantial contributions to many nonprofit groups, including the New York University Child Study Center, of which I am director. The center integrates research of childhood psychiatric disorders with clinical work.

Critics have said that philanthropic contributions from Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic candidate for Senate in New Jersey, were linked to political favors (news article, Oct. 9). But long before he decided to run for office, Mr. Corzine made substantial contributions to many nonprofit groups, including the New York University Child Study Center, of which I am director. The center integrates research of childhood psychiatric disorders with clinical work.

Mr. Corzine is one of those rare people who give anonymously and without an overt or hidden agenda. Having strong advocates and supporters like Mr. Corzine and his wife, Joanne, has allowed the center to undertake research in violence prevention and establish programs in economically challenged communities. HAROLD S. KOPLEWICZ, M.D. New York, Oct. 9, 2000
